titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.26 (21 June-28 June 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 26. Mercurius Publicus: COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence; WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order of the late Council of State. From Thur≈øday June 21. to Thur≈øday June 28. 1660.

div.p:
YE≈øterday the Baron of Pelnitz, the Ma≈øter of the Hor≈øe, Chamberlain and Colonel of the Regiment of the Guards of his Electoral Highne≈øs of Brandenbourgh, and his Extraordinary Envoy to his Maje≈øty, had Audience at VVhitehal. The Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies went to fetch him from his Hou≈øe, with two rich Coaches, each with ≈øix Hor≈øes, and ≈øo conducted him to VVhitehal; being brought
up ≈øtairs, the Vice Chamberlain conducted him through a gallery full on both ≈øides of Gentlemen, unto the Pre≈øence Chamber door, where the Earl of Manche≈øter, Lord Chamberlain, conducted him to his Maje≈øty, who ≈øtaid expecting him there. His Maje≈øty was bare during the whole audience: his Speech was pretty long, containing a congratulation upon the happy re≈øtauration of his Maje≈øty, and the expre≈ø≈øion of his „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Highne≈ø≈øes joy for the ≈øame. His Maje≈øty returned a very obliging an≈øwer, ≈øuitable to the affection that ‚Ä¢ lector hath ≈øhewed unto him in former times, being the fir≈øt forreign Mini≈øter with Credentials to his Maje≈øty that made a publick addre≈øs. The Audience being ended, the Lord Chamberlain conducted him back through the ≈øaid Gallery to the ≈øtairs head, the Vice Chamberlain to the Coach, and the Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies, with another Gentleman, and the two Coaches brought him home again, an honor we have not heard of conferred before on any forreign Envoy, by a King of England, and now done to ≈øhew the high ≈øentiments his Maje≈øty hath of the Electors former kindne≈øs to him.

A Letter from Lievtenant Col. Yardly, to M. Thomas A≈øht ‚Ä¢ n, Chaplain to the Engli≈øh in Jer≈øey, was communicated to his Excellency General Monck, containing the ≈øole unity of his Maje≈øties Proclamation there, by his order a ≈øta ‚Ä¢ ely Sc ‚Ä¢ ffold was erected in the market place of S. Hillaries Town, where were pre≈øent all the Engli≈øh Officers and Souldiers, and the Hon ‚Ä¢ rable Sir Philip Cartaret, and the chief of the Gentry, the Proclamation was in Engli≈øh and French, after each followed volleys of ≈øhot, and loud acclamations of God ≈øave King CHARLES the Second; at night the ayr was lighted with bonfires, and the I≈øland thundred with the great Guns, at lea≈øt a hundred ≈øhots were made from them in that ≈ømall place, con≈øi≈øting but of
twelve Pari≈øhes, the like rejoycing was never known there in any ones memory now living; 'tis di≈øputable whether the Engli≈øh or the I≈ølanders were more cordial, or ≈øaw more ≈øigns of thankfulne≈øs, but 'tis out of controver≈øie, that his Maje≈øty hath not more loyal Subjects in his Dominions, their obedience being confirmed by the pre≈øence of his Maje≈øty among them after his Fathers death of ble≈ø≈øed memory, and his own miraculous deliverance at Worce≈øter fight, which ≈øo encrea≈øed their courage, that Ier≈øey was the la≈øt place lo≈øt from his Maje≈øty, being kept by the faithful and couragious Sir George Cartaret, until his Maje≈øty ≈øent him an Expre≈øs out of France to ≈øurrender it.
Upon a report from the Committee of Priviledges and Elections concerning the Return of the Election for Scarborough.
Re≈øolved, That M. Tomp≈øon is duly Elected to ≈øerve as a Member in Parliament for that place.

M. Luke Robin≈øon being cho≈øen for that place, and by former order di≈øcharged from ≈øitting in the Hou≈øe, it was ordered that a new Writ i≈ø≈øue for the electing of a new Burgre≈øs to ≈øerve in his ≈øtead.
Upon report concerning the Election of the Borough of Northampton.
Re≈øolved, That Sir John Norris and M. Rainsford, are duly elected for that place.
M. Carew, one of the Tryers of the late King, being brought up, and delivered to the Speaker, and by him committed to the Serjeant at Arms, the Hou≈øe approved of his commitment.

M. Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe, that the Lord Mon≈øon came with his Keeper from the Fleet, and ≈øurrendred him≈øelf to him according to his Maje≈øties Proclamation; whom the Speaker finding to to be a Pri≈øoner upon Execution, remanded back to the Fleet, which the Hou≈øe approved of.

M. Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe, that Major General
Ludlow had rendered him≈øelf: whereupon it was ordered, that he be committed to the Serjeant at Arms.

The Hou≈øe referred it to a Committee, to ≈øtate the Accompts of all ≈øuch who have provided Nece≈ø≈øaries in order to his Maje≈øties Reception; and to give Warrants for their ≈øatisfaction out of the 20000 l. charged upon the Bill of A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øement for that purpo≈øe.
Upon Report of amendments to the Bill for confirming of Priviledges of Parliament and the fundamental Laws, they were agreed unto, and the Bill ordered to be engro≈ø≈øed.
The Bill for Pole-money was read the ≈øecond time, and ordered to be committed to a grand Committee of the Hou≈øe, and that the Hou≈øe be in a grand Committee to morrow morning for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: London.
div.p: This day the ≈øeveral Aldermen and other Citizens of London, waited upon their Highne≈ø≈øes, the Duke of York and Duke of Gloce≈øter, to de≈øire them to honour the City with their company at Dinner at Guild-hall, on the day his Maje≈øty had appointed to dine with them; going to the Hou≈øe of Lords, thence to the Hou≈øe of Commons, whom they al≈øo invited the ≈øame day: who were plea≈øed to accept of the Invitation, and return their thanks for the Cities re≈øpect to them.

div.head: We≈øtminster, Thur≈øday June 21. 1660.
div.p:
Ordered by the Lords and Commons new a≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ led in Parliament, That one Sub≈øidie called Tonnage
‚Ä¢ nd one other Sub≈øidie called Poundage, and tho≈øe other Duties called or known by the name of New-Impo≈øt, ≈øhall continue to be paid after the Rates, Rules ‚Ä¢ nd Proportions by which they are now due and payab ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and upon the ≈øame Goods and Merchandizes whereupon the ≈øame are now levied and collected, until the 24th of Iuly, which ≈øhall be in the year of our Lord, 1660; before which time, one Act is intended
to be pa≈ø≈øed for the Settlement and Regulation thereof.

Ordered by the Lords and Commons now a≈øsembled in Parliament, That the Impo≈øition of Exci≈øe ≈øhall continue to be paid after the Rates, Rules, and Proportions by which the ≈øame is now due and payable, and upon the ≈øame Goods and Merchandizes, whereupon the ≈øame are now levied and collected, until the twenty fourth of Iuly, which ≈øhall be in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred and ≈øixty, before which time, one Act is intended to be pa≈ø≈øed for the Settlement and Regulation thereof.

div.head: Friday, Iune 22. At the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: The Hou≈øe of Lords having received a Me≈ø≈øage from the Hou≈øe of Commons to de≈øire their concurrence in ordering 10000l. part of the 20000l. formerly conferred by the Parliament on the Lord General Monck. to be paid out of the Ordinance of A≈ø≈øe≈øsment for 70000l. per men≈øem, their Lord≈øhips agreed thereunto.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: Upon Report made of Amendments to the Bill of General Pardon and Oblivion, the Amendments were agreed unto and the Bill Ordered to be engro≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ d. The Bill is to extend to the 24th. of Iune, 1660.

Re≈øolved, That Mr. Burton be one of the twenty excepted out of the General Act of Indempnity and Oblivion to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, &c. and now in the Cu≈øtody of the Serjeant, have liberty to attend his occa≈øions, upon ≈øecurity given to the Serjeant at Armes to be forth coming when he ≈øhall require him thereunto.
The Bill for ≈øetling Judicial Proceedings was ordered to be read to morrow morning.
The ‚Ä¢ ule Re≈øolved to be in a Grand Committee at three of the clock in the afternoon, which was done accordingly.
A Petition of Lancelot Emmet and others was read and referred to a Committee.
Ordered, That the Hou≈øe be in a Grand Committee on Monday next at three of the clock in the afternoon to con≈øider of a Bill touching the Court of Wardes.
Ordered, That the Committee who are to con≈øider of Mini≈øters Livings do meet this afternoon, and ≈øo de die in diem, and that they ≈øpeedily report the ≈øame.
Re≈øolved, That the Hou≈øe be in a Grand Committee on Munday next to con≈øider of Poll-money.

Upon Report made upon examination of the Accompt of Richard Blackwell, John Sparrow, and Humphry Blake, that there was due to the State from them for Arrears of Prize-Goods, from the year 1649. to the year 1652. 41495.5 s. 3 d. ¬º. It was Ordered,

That it be referred to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Trea≈øury, to take ≈øpeedy cour≈øe for the calling of the ≈øaid Richard Blackwel, Iohn Sparrow, and Humphry Blake, to an accompt in the Exchequer, and that they be proceeded again≈øt.
The Bill for ≈øatisfaction of Purcha≈øes was read, and ordered to be read again.

The Hou≈øe re≈øolved, That the Queens Maje≈øty ≈øhall be re≈øtored to the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe Hou≈øes, Mannors and Lands following, being part of her Maje≈øties Joynture, and purcha≈øed by ≈øuch Per≈øons who≈øe E≈øtates are lyable to forfeiture, viz.
Mannor of Old-Court, purcha≈øed by M. Edwards.
Mannor of Richmond, with Hou≈øe and Materials, pucha≈øed by Sir Gregory Norton.
Egghant purcha≈øed by Captain John Blackwel.
Mannor of Ampthil, and Mannor of Milbrooke, purcha≈øed by Col. Okey.
Mannor of Somer≈øham, with the Cha≈øe and Pa ‚Ä¢ k, Mannor of Crowland, Part Mannor of Spalding, purcha≈øed by Col. Wauton, and Adrian Scroop.
Part of the Mannor of Ea≈øtham, purcha≈øed by M. Blackwel.
Mannor of We≈øt-Walton, and Mannor of Trington, purcha≈øed by Ed. Whaley.
Honour and Mannor of Eye, purcha≈øed by M. Dendy.
Non-≈øuch great Park and Materials, purcha≈øed by Col. Pride.
Non-≈øuch Hou≈øe and Park, purcha≈øed bp Col. Lambert.

Re≈øolved That Sommer≈øet Hou≈øe and Greenwich, be likewi≈øe forthwith re≈øtored to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of her Maje≈øty, and that all Arrears of rent be paid unto her Maje≈øty, unto ≈øuch per≈øons as her Maje≈øty ≈øhall be plea≈øed to appoint to receive the ≈øame.
Ordered, That the Hou≈øe be in a Grand Committee on Munday „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Poll-money.

div.head: Whitehall
div.p:
On Fryday, the Right Honourable the Earl of Winc ‚Ä¢ el≈øe ‚Ä¢ , with ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e oth ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tlemen, pre≈øented an Addre≈øs to his Sacred Maje≈øty, ≈øub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Nobility and Gentry of Kent, wherein they expre≈øs their great joy „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Maje≈øtie ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
ration to his people; as al≈øo their con≈øtant loyalty and heart ‚Ä¢ affection to his Maje≈øty. His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to „Äà‚óä„Äâ them tha ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Journey through that C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ty he had ≈øufficient evidence of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Pe ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ e; and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of his Gracious favour to them upon any occa≈øion that „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

The ≈øame night his Maje≈øty, with his two R ‚Ä¢ yal B ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, and ≈øeveral of „Äà‚óä„Äâ N ‚Ä¢
bility, were highly entertained a ‚Ä¢ Supper by the Lo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Lu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ y.

Saturday being appointed by his Maje≈øty to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uch ≈øuch as were troubled with the Evil, a great company of p ‚Ä¢ or affl ‚Ä¢ cted Crea ‚Ä¢ ures were „Äà‚óä„Äâ together, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Chairs and F ‚Ä¢ askets, and being appointed by his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to the Banqu ‚Ä¢ ting-hou≈øe, his Maje≈øty ≈øat in a Chair of Sta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , where he ≈øt ‚Ä¢ ok'd „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ we „Äà‚óä„Äâ to him, and then put about each of their N ‚Ä¢ cks a white R ‚Ä¢ bb ‚Ä¢ n with an A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ Gold on it. In this manner his Maje≈øty ≈øtroak' ‚Ä¢ abov ‚Ä¢ 6 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and ≈øuch was his „Äà‚óä„Äâ p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ience and tenderne≈øs to the poor affl ‚Ä¢ cted Creatures „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ took up a „Äà‚óä„Äâ long time, His Maje≈øty being never weary of wel-doing, was plea≈øed to make enqui ‚Ä¢ y w ‚Ä¢ ether there were any more that had not yet been touch'd. A ‚Ä¢ ter Prayers were ended, the Duke of Buckingham brought a Towel, and the Earl o ‚Ä¢
Pembrook a Ba≈øo ‚Ä¢ and E ‚Ä¢ er, who after they had made their obey≈øance to his Maje≈øty, kneeled down till his M ‚Ä¢ je≈øty had wa≈øhed.

div.head: We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p: On Satarday, ≈øeveral Gentlemen of the Long Robe were made Serjeants of the Coi ‚Ä¢ e. They came out of the Common P ‚Ä¢ eas Trea≈øu ‚Ä¢ y, in ‚Ä¢ o We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, and ≈øtood over again≈øt the Common Pl ‚Ä¢ as Court, Serjeant Glanvil, and Serjeant Littleton, brought them to the Bar according to the u≈øual form, the Wa ‚Ä¢ den of the Fleet, and U ‚Ä¢ her of the Exchequer walking before them. The names of the≈øe made Serjeant ‚Ä¢ are, Sir Tho. Widderington, Serj. Brown, Serj. Gly ‚Ä¢ , Serj. Earle, Serj. Bernars ‚ñ™ Serj. Hales. Serj. Twi≈øden, Serj. Maynard, Serj. New ‚Ä¢ igate, Serj. Windham, Serj. Fountain, Serj. Sy≈øe, Serj Archer, Serj. Waller.

After ≈øo many ≈øeveral Reports of the Enterpri≈øe of Generali≈øsimo Moro≈øini, we hear by Letters from him to the Senate, that having retired his Forces from about Negroponte, the Fort whereof would have kept too long his Army, he hath upon a ≈øudden fallen upon the I≈øle of S ‚Ä¢ atto, not ab ‚Ä¢ ve 20 miles di≈øtance from the other, and before the Enemies could recover them≈øelves, did ≈øo vigorou≈øly a≈ø≈øault the Ca≈øtle, that notwith≈øtanding the re≈øi ‚Ä¢ tance of tho≈øe within, he took it two days after, wherein he found 70 Pieces of Ordnance, with Prov ‚Ä¢ ≈øions for a moneth for his whole Army. Thus his de≈øign was to demoli≈øh it,
that he might hereafter ≈øo much the more ea≈øily get the Contributions of that I≈øle. We hear from Con≈øtantinople that the Grand Signior is yet at Andrinople, where he doth remain by the advice of the Divan, to ha≈øten the march of the Forces de≈øigned again≈øt Prince Ragotski. That the fir≈øt Vizier is returned thither from Belgrade, hoping the change of air will much contribute to the recovering of his health‚ñ™ and that the Grand Signor never mi≈ø≈øed a day without giving him a vi≈øit, and asking his advice upon his affairs. In the mean while, having need of all his Forces, upon an enquiry into the ≈øtate of his Militia in pay, he hath found 120000 F ‚Ä¢ ot and 40000 Hor≈øe, be≈øides his ordinary Guards, which are above 10000 men, with 50 Gallies, 12 Mahones, 30 great ≈øhips and many ≈ømall ones. The Letters ≈øay further that the ≈øaid Grand Signor ≈øeemed to be very much troubled for the Peace between France and Spain, not doubting but that his Empire, which u≈øeth to take advantage of the divi≈øion among the Chri≈øtian Princes, will ≈øuffer by their re-union. And indeed, be≈øides the 4 Gallies of the Pope, the 7 of Maltha, and the 3 of the Great Duke of Tu≈øcany, which have been ≈øeen about Corfeu and Zante, going to joyn with our Fleet, we hear that the French ≈øhips, carrying Forces thither, were not very far. We hear by a Ship come from the ≈øaid I≈øle of Zante, that three French private Men of War, under the Commi≈ø≈øions of Maltha, having lately faln in the Seas of Rhodes, upon a Sultana going from Alexandria towards Con≈øtantinople, as a Convoy to ≈øome Saicks, took the third Sultana, and two of the Saicks, having killed two hundred Turks, who defended them≈øelves very re≈øolutely for five houres together. That Prize, valued above 400000 Crowns, hath been carried to Maltha.

div.head: St. John de Luz, 14 June, 1660.
div.p: Be≈øides the particulars mentioned in my la≈øt, concerning the la≈øt Ceremonies of the Kings Marriage, I have the≈øe following to adde, that you might have a perfect account of that extraordinary occa≈øion. The Church of this place having been prepared before with all po≈ø≈øible pomp for ≈øuch an augu≈øt ≈øolemnity, all the Court repaired thither about Noon, by a Bridge made purpo≈øely from the Queen Mothers lodgings to the ≈øaid Church, whereof both ≈øides were guarded by a double File of the French and Switzers Guards. The Kings Mu≈øquetiers on Hor≈øeback, were in the middle of the place before the Kings Hou≈øe, all in new and rich Ca≈ø≈øecks. The Company of the Archers of the Grand Provo≈øt of the King's Hou≈øhold went before, then that of the 100 Switzers, the Kings Footmen, the Pages of the great and ≈ømall Stables in great number; tho≈øe of his Maje≈øties Bed-chamber, all in new and magnificent Liveries, and ≈øeveral Grandees in black Clothes, with Cloaks lined with Golden Stuffs, and laces black mingled with imbroidery of Gold. Then came alone Cardinal Mazarine, 12 Gentlemen of the Ordnance, round about him. After him came the King richly apparelled, and marching in great Maje≈øty between the Marquis of Peguillen and the Marquis of Humieres, and two Gentlemen of his Chamber on each ≈øide. The Marquis de Charo≈øt, Captain of the Guards followed him, with two of the ≈øaid Guards. Then came the Queen with her retinue, after the manner expre≈ø≈øed in my la≈øt. The Queen Mother came after, very joyfull of the occa≈øion of the ceremony of that day, to which ≈øhe contributed mo≈øt of all. She was led by her Knight of Honour, and one of her Gentlem ‚Ä¢ n U≈øhers, the Counte≈øs of Flex her Lady of Honour carrying her Train. Madamoi≈øelle followed, having her Train carried by M. de Mancini. The Ladies a ‚Ä¢ d Maids of the two Queens clo≈øed the march, being followed by the Queen Mothers Guards: Abundance of Trumpets were blowing all the while. The Ceremonies of the Church you had in my former Letters, as al≈øo the particulars of that days Ceremonies at home.

The next day, their Maje≈øties went to the Recollects Church to their Devotions, and about night went to take the air by the ≈øea-≈øide. The ≈øame day, the Cardinal Mazarine had another conference in the I≈øle with Don Louis de Aro, about the remaining differences of ≈øome of the Allies. The 12. the Popes Nuntio, the Amba≈ø≈øadors of Venice, the Re≈øident of Genoa, the Envoy of their Royal Highne≈ø≈øes of S ‚Ä¢ voy, and the Deputies of the Parliament and Chamber of Accounts of Pau ‚Ä¢ , being conducted by Mr. de Chabenas-Bonnevil, had Audience of their Maje≈øties. Mr. Akakia hath brought hither the Treaty of Peace between Swedeland and Poland, to be ratified by the King, as Mediatour between tho≈øe two Crowns. To morrow their Maje≈øties are to depart from hence for Bayonne; from whence the next day to Aix, and from thence through the little Lands to Bourdeaux.

div.head: Mar≈øeille the 15 of June 1660.
div.p: The 9 in≈øtant two Gallies coming from Italy came to our Iles, carrying into Spain the Prince Ludovi≈øio. They went from thence the 13 following; and the ≈øame day the Duke of Mercoeur came hither from Aix to ha≈øten the work of our Cittadel, having ≈øent hither before above 300 new workmen.

div.head: Am≈øterdam the 17 of June 1660.
div.p:
The 14 in≈øtant the Prince≈øs Royal, and the Prince of Orange her ≈øon came hither, and were received by our Inhabitants; of whom 3 Companies under their arms and richly apparelled, the foot of our ordinary Guard, and all our Young men were gone out to meet them, and brought them in with a great Co ‚Ä¢ tage of Coaches, and 18 Chariots of Triumph prepared for their reception. All our great Guns were ≈øhot off, and an≈øwered by the Artillery of above 150 ≈øhips in our Port: ≈øince that time there hath been nothing here but Fea≈øtings and rejoycings, either publick or private, whereof the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Inhabitants of the Neighbouring towns, who came hither purpo≈øely, have been partakers. The Peace between Sueden and Denmark is confirmed; all Europe
≈øeeming now to have ≈øhaken off the War to imbrace the Peace this Province following their example hath already con≈øented to an accomodation with Portugal.

div.head: Paris the 26 of June 1660.
div.p: Ye≈øterday the Te Deum was ≈øung here in the Church of our Lady for the happy accompli≈øhment of the Kings Marriage. The Chancellor with the whole Council of the King, the Parliament, the Chamber of Accounts and the Court of Aids having been ≈øummoned to be there by the Kings order, delivered them by M. du Pin, Aide of the Ceremonies, were pre≈øent thereunto, with the body of the Officers of this City, and an infinite number of per≈øons of Quality. At night the Bonfires were made every where in our ≈øtreets, and all our windoes were full of lights, and our Cannon ≈øpoke our joy by break of day. We hear that the Court arrived at Bayonne the 15 in≈øtant, and was to go the next day for Bourdeaux. The 22 the Prince arrived here from Bourdeaux, where he hath left the Court. He hath been but three dayes upon the way.

div.head: Stockholm the 26 of May 1660.
div.p: Nothing is ye ‚Ä¢ concluded in the Treaty with the Grand Duke of Mu≈øcovy: the chief of our Emba≈ø≈øy to him, the Lord Beng Horn is returned hither ≈øome five dayes ≈øince to take new Orders of the young King; and we hear that likewi≈øe the Ru≈ø≈øian Commi≈ø≈øioners are gone to their Ma≈øter upon the ≈øame account: but we hear the ≈øaid Grand Duke will not hearken to re≈øtore ≈øuch places as he hath lately taken in Liffeland, although he hath heard of the conclu≈øion of the Treaty between this ‚Ä¢ rown and Poland. On our ≈øide we are re≈øolved never to yield unto that, nor relinqui≈øh our right to tho≈øe places. The Emba≈ø≈øador of the ≈øaid Duke that was here, hath been di≈ømi≈øt pre≈øently upon the advice hereof, he being thought to be only here as an honourable Spy. 30 Ba ‚Ä¢ ks are here ready to tran≈øport our Army to Nerve upon the Borders of Mo≈øco ‚Ä¢ y, to be ready in ca≈øe of a breach, which is thought to be like to in≈øue upon this between this Crown and that Duke.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: ‚òûA Smooth Black Dog, le≈øs then a Grey-hound, with white under his brea≈øt, belonging to the Kings Maje≈øty, was taken from Whitehall, the eighteenth day of this in≈øtant June, or there about. If any one can give notice to John Elles one of his Maje≈øties Servants, or to his Maje≈øties Back-≈øtairs, ≈øhall be well rewarded for their labour.

A Brown bay Mare, blind of one eye, ≈øtolen from We≈øton in the Thi≈øtles, in the County of Warwick, on the 17 of June in≈øtant. Give notice to Mr. John Andrews at the White hor≈øe in Dairy-Lane, or to the Swan at Shipton upon Stower, and receive a good rewa ‚Ä¢ d.

I∆≤ne 13. Stolen out of Pa≈øture near Stratford by Bow, A Bay Nag, with a frizled tail, no ‚Ä¢ hite, peel'd in the Face, the hair being off, trots and paces, thirteen handfull high ≈øix years old. Al≈øo a ‚Ä¢ hite grey Nag, t ‚Ä¢ ors all, clorded about one eye, about twelve handfull high, nine year old. If any one can give notice at the ≈øign of the Cro≈øs-Keys in Holborn, or at the Po≈øt hou≈øe in London, ≈øhall be well rewarded for their pains.

div.head: Munday, June 25. 1660. Re≈øolved by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament,
div.p: THat no per≈øon what≈øoever do pre≈øume at his peril to Print any Votes or Proceedings of this Hou≈øe, without the ≈øpecial leave and order of the Hou≈øe,

closer.signed: W. Je≈ø≈øop Clerk of the Commons Ho ‚Ä¢ ≈øe of Parliament.

div.head: Hamborough June 12. 1660.
div.p: In con≈øequence of the peace between the two Northern Kings, the pri≈øoners of War at Gluck≈øtrade have been relea≈øed by order of the King of Denmark; and among other the Prince of Anhalt, and the Lieutenant General Horne, who are ≈øince arrived here. By Letters from Coppenhagen of the 5 in≈øtant, we hear That the Suedes are gone from the Leagure before that City, from whence two ≈øhips had been ≈øent to the Ile of Fal≈øter to ≈øhip them away. The Lord Hannibal See≈øtede, and the Lord Slinglandt are ≈øent into Suedland; the fir≈øt from the King of Denmark, and the ≈øecond from the States General of the United Provinces; not only to condole the death of the late King of Sueden, but al≈øo to congratulate the coming of the pre≈øent King to the Crown. The Suedi≈øh Army lyes ≈øtill in Zealand, expecting the orders from the Suedi≈øh Court for their next imployment. The allyed forces in Jutland and Hol≈øtein do ≈øtill lye there, and nothing is yet given out of their marching away. The Peace hath been publi≈øhed in the Dukedome of Bremen.

div.head: From Edenburgh, June 19.
div.p: Out of the affection I have for you, I have with every conveniency acquainted you with what pa≈ø≈øeth here worthy of your knowledge or ob≈øervation, and at this time e≈øpecially, I have made bold to borrow a few minutes from the publick Solemnities, to give you that in brief which we are celebrating with that ≈øplendor and affection and unfeign ‚Ä¢ d tokens of joy, that the like hath not been ≈øeen before in this Nation; for great and wonderfull is the Lords work of deliverance in that day when we expected to be overturned with confu≈øion, and covered with de≈øolation.

The Magi≈øtrates of this City and our Presbytery, being mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible of the great mercy received, did appoint this the day of their publick Thank≈øgiving to God for his ≈øignal love and kindne≈øs ≈øhewed to them, in inve≈øting our mo≈øt gracious Soveraign with his Thrones of England and Ireland, and for re≈øtoring him to his Government over this his ancient Nation, that for twenty hundred years hath flouri≈øhed under the Scepter of his Royal Ance≈øtors. And have given notice of this their re≈øolution to all the Burghs and P ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ byte ‚Ä¢ ies of Scotland, de≈øiring their concurrence, that as their Cau≈øe is, ≈øo their joy may be univer≈øal: Our Mini≈øters in their Sermons with ≈øo much fervency and pa≈ø≈øionate expre≈ø≈øions delivered what great kindne≈øs the Lord had for us, in re≈øtoring to us our good King, that it hath not been ob≈øerved that at any time their E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tations have b ‚Ä¢ en entertained with ≈øuch attention, and ≈øo plentifull tears, by their Audito ‚Ä¢ y. The Engli≈øh Officers of State and Warre ob≈øerved the
Thank≈øgiving with no le≈øs joy and devotion after Sermon, and after we had all dined together, we all marched from the Council-hou≈øe to the Cro≈øs, in this order, The Town Council in their Gowns, with their trumpets ≈øounding before them, went fir≈øt, then two Bailies before the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners and Officers, and two behind them went next‚ñ™ The Provo≈øt all alone before the Scots Nobility and Gentry that are in Town, and two Bailies with the Dean of Gild and The≈øaurer followed after. Their Guards, neer ≈øix hundred Citizens in comely apparel, armed with Swords and Parti≈øans, the Cro≈øs was covered with Artificial Vines loaden with Grapes, both good Cla
‚Ä¢ et wines plentifully ≈øpringing out from all its Channels. On its heads a Baccus be≈øtradling a Hog≈øhead with two or three Satyrs, did with their mimick g ‚Ä¢ ≈øtures and je≈øts entertain the beholders. A little below the Cro≈øs, within a Rail was errected a Scaffold ≈øix foot high, on which was placed a large Table covered with a rich Banquet ≈øerved up in gla≈øs, and repre≈øenting divers forms and devices as his Maje≈øties Arms, the Arms of the City; and divers Exotick Trees vvere rai≈øed, loaden with their Leaves and Fruits, &c. The Table being ≈øurrounded with above one hundred per≈øons of Eminency. The Mu≈øick and breaking of Gla≈ø≈øes vvere ≈øeconded by three general Vollies of the Hor≈øe and Foot, vvho received as hand≈øome an≈øvver from the great Guns of the Ca≈øtle, Ci ‚Ä¢ adel and ≈øhips in the Road; and all were ec ‚Ä¢ hoed by joyful Acclamations of the people.

After this the forces drew off, affording the civilities of view to the people, among≈øt whom the di≈øhes and banquet were hurled, and ≈øo aro≈øe and marched down to the Piazzo of the Palace of Holyrod hou≈øe, fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt the Commi≈ø≈øioners, nex ‚Ä¢ the Mayor General wi ‚Ä¢ h his Army, and after them the City Magi≈øtrates with their guards; whence after the Masket had ≈øaluted them there with divers vollios, and had ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ceived a retu ‚Ä¢ n from the great guns of the Ca≈øtle citadal and ≈øea, as formerly they marched back again quite thorough the City up to the Ca≈øt ‚Ä¢ e-hill, from w ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e every one part returned to ≈øpend the re≈øt of the evening with their friends in mirth and mutual joy and entertainments. But now begin in the Bells and the Fireworks, therefore I mu≈øt be gone to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the dances of our Magi≈øtrates and Ci ‚Ä¢ izen abou ‚Ä¢ the Bonefires, and on my knees to remember ‚Ä¢ he health of my Soveraign and his loyal kindred, and the pro≈øperity of his Excellency and all tho≈øe Heroes and No ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ les who have been in≈øtrum ‚Ä¢ ntal, or do rejoyce with us in this our great deliverance and happine≈øs.

div.head: D ‚Ä¢ e Sabbati, Junii 23. 1660.
div.p: ORdered by the Lords in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, That all the Tyths, Gleb ‚Ä¢ s, and other Profits of, or belonging to the Rectory of A. B. in the County of D. C. and other Eccle≈øia≈øtical Living or Benefice of A. B. who hath been Sequ ‚Ä¢ ≈øtred or Ejected without due cour≈øe of Law, in or ≈øince the time of the late Warr, be by Authority hereof ≈øtayed and ≈øecured, in the hands of the Church-Warden, or Over- ‚Ä¢ eers to the Poor of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, untill the Title of the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ eque≈øtred A. B. and the pre≈øent Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor thereof ≈øhall be determined by the further Order of Parliament, or Eviction by due cour≈øe of Law.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: His Sacred Maje≈øty, but of a ≈øence of the high de≈øerts of Col. John Covert u ‚Ä¢ Glaug ‚Ä¢ am, in the county of Suffex, (who formerly ≈øerved in the Army of his ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Maje≈øty of ever ble≈ø≈øed memory with much courage and fidelity, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øince that, notwith≈øtanding the cruelty of his enemies, and their per≈øecuting of him for continuing his allegiance to his pre≈øent Maje≈øty, ≈øtill remained un≈øhaken in his re≈øolutions to perform his duty, for which he was by Oliver Cromwell impri≈øoned in the Tower) was graciou≈øly plea≈øed fir≈øt to Knight him, and then give him a Patent for Baroner.

His Maje≈øty conferred the honour of Knighthood on William Poult ‚Ä¢ ty, a per≈øon that ever had a great civility for all that were for the Royal cau≈øe, and a loyal heart for his Maje≈øties ≈øervice.
Col. Roger Mo≈øtyn is made Gentleman of the privy chamber to his Maje≈øty to enjoy all priviledges, &c.
On Munday, the right honourable the Earl of Shrewsbury pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty an Addre≈øs of the Nobility and Gentry of the County of Worce≈øter enti ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ ed.

p.hi: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, The humble Addre≈øs of the Nobility and Gentry in the County of Worce≈øter.

div.p: The Addre≈øs was ≈øub≈øcribed, Tho. Wind≈øor, Tho. Coventry, Will. Ru≈ø≈øell, and above fifty others. His Maje≈øty returned them his hearty thanks, telling them, He was well a≈ø≈øured of their Loyalty and affection, and ≈øhould ever have a good e≈øteem of them.
One Payne, formerly a Me≈ø≈øenger of Oliver Cromwell, is ≈øecured; there being information again≈øt him, That he was the Executioner of that Execrable m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ der of his late Maje≈øty.
On Monday Serjeant Atkins, a per≈øon of knowen integritie and great learning in the Law, ≈øate Baron of the Exchequer.

It being prohibited by the Hou≈øe of Commons, upon the mi≈øcarriage and abu≈øes of ≈øome idle Pamphletters, That any of the Votes of that Hou≈øe ≈øhould be printed without ≈øpecial Order, the Reader is de≈øired to excu≈øe us, if in obedien ‚Ä¢ e to them we cannot yet give him ≈øo full ≈øatisfaction.

Books from the Office of Intelligence having formerly given you an account that Mr. Scot, one of the late pretended High Count of Ju≈øtice for trial of his late Maje≈øty was brought to We≈øtmin≈øter; I mu≈øt confe≈øs, though enquired of by many, I could not give ≈øatisfaction therein, being tender to gain≈øay any thing I did not well know, e≈øpecially in a matter concerning Mr. Scot, with whom that Pamphl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ter formerly kept ≈øuch con≈øtant intelligence; till meeting with a near relation of his, I was informed that he was at Bru≈ø≈øels, where he had tended him≈øelf to Sir Henry de V ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , till his Maje≈øties plea≈øure ≈øhould be further known concerning him; laying him≈øelf now at la≈øt at the feet of his Maje≈øties mercy as his onely ≈øecurity.

From Ireland we are certified, that there are yet ≈øome unquiet ≈øpirits among≈øt them, which do endeavour to bring that Nation again into confu≈øion, as may appear by a Letter lately taken, of dangerous con≈øequence; the intent of it is to ≈øtir
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to a new War. But being by providence ≈øo early found out, their Plot is doubtle≈øs quite ≈øpoiled. For ≈øuch is the prodence and valour of the per≈øons intru≈øted with the management of affairs in that Nation, that we need not fear, had they headed, much le≈øs now the De≈øign ‚Ä¢ s di≈øcovered.
London, Printed by J: Macock, and Tho. Newcomb, 1660.
